definition: to encumber/to be a burden on/to implicate
to drag/to tow/to trail/to hang down/to mop (the floor)/to delay/to drag on
tired/weary/to strain/to wear out/to work hard
to accumulate/to involve or implicate (Taiwan pr. [lei4])/continuous/repeated

sentences.english: But Shenzhen Stock Cheng Zhi, because is implicated the bank tectonic plate is small, bounce dynamics is slightly big.
sentences.chinese: 而深證成指由於受銀行板塊拖累較小，反彈力度稍大。

sentences.english: One should not encumber oneself with hire purchase repayments at the beginning of a marriage.
sentences.chinese: 人不應該在婚姻的開始就被買賣的租金所拖累。

sentences.english: Each of these measures is a small drag on growth in the economy.
sentences.chinese: 這兩套措施分別看都是美國經濟增長的小拖累。

sentences.english: That could weigh on growth, and intensify frictions over trade.
sentences.chinese: 這可能會拖累經濟增長，並加劇貿易摩擦。
或者，你現在應該明白我指的那“拖累”是誰？

sentences.english: One consequence is a demographic crisis that is expected to drag down growth.
sentences.chinese: 其後果就是人口危機拖累增長。

sentences.english: She was cumbered with household cares.
He refused to lumber himself with a family.
The life sunset of mother, could it be said that is encumbrance of your livings or careers?
sentences.chinese: 一個母親的晚年，難道是我們生活或事業的拖累嗎？

sentences.english: Had it not been for his family, He'd have gone away long ago .
sentences.chinese: 要是沒有家眷拖累，他早就遠走高飛了。

sentences.english: They can't encumber us on the road.
sentences.chinese: 他們不會在路上拖累大家。

sentences.english: Look presentable, but don’t obsess over your appearance.
sentences.chinese: 外表要看的過去，但別被你的外表拖累。

sentences.english: Oscillation heavyweights also fell, dragged down part of the index.
sentences.chinese: 權重股也振盪回落，部分拖累了指數。

sentences.english: All rudders cause drag, both when steering the boat and in the "neutral" position.
sentences.chinese: 所有舵造成拖累，既當督導船並在“中立”立場。

sentences.english: Dont's want to cumber with my teacher.
sentences.chinese: 不願拖累老師獨自流汗。

sentences.english: To a certain extent, mankind encumbers the Earth.
sentences.chinese: 在一定程度上，人類拖累了地球。

definition: to slow/to slow down (the pace of)
superfluous/cumbersome/a burden on sb/a nuisance to sb/to inconvenience/to tie sb down/long-winded (of writing)/also pr. [lei2 zhui5]
to be put to a lot of trouble
to get dragged into/to get involved (on sb else's account)
one stumble, unable to rise (idiom); a setback leading to total collapse/ruined at a stroke/unable to recover after a minor hitch
